title: 111_hr3040
content: The Act may be cited as the "Senior Financial Empowerment Act of 2010". The Congress finds that the population of Americans aged 60 and older is expected to significantly increase in the next 30 years due to the aging Baby Boomer generation. Between 500,000 and 5,000,000 seniors in the US are abused, neglected, or exploited annually, with financial exploitation being a common issue. Fraud targeting seniors is difficult to estimate due to severe underreporting. Seniors in the US are often targeted for fraud, with cases being severely underreported. The Federal Bureau of Investigation notes that seniors are less likely to report fraud due to various reasons such as not knowing who to report to, feeling ashamed, or not realizing they have been victims. Additionally, concerns about mental capacity may prevent seniors from reporting fraud. A 2009 report estimated that victims of senior financial abuse lose at least $2.6 billion annually. Financial abuse targeting seniors is estimated to cost at least $2.6 billion annually. Perpetrators of fraud often operate outside the US, using deceptive mailings to reach victims. Seniors are vulnerable to fraud due to their trusting nature, leading to financial and emotional costs. The Deceptive Mail Prevention and Enforcement Act has increased the power of the US Postal Service to protect consumers. During fiscal year 2007, Postal Inspection Service analysts responded to mail fraud complaints by preparing over 27,000 letters and postcards. They investigated 2,909 mail fraud cases, resulting in 1,236 arrests and 1,118 convictions. Additionally, 162 telemarketing fraud investigations led to 83 arrests and 61 convictions. The United States Senate Special Committee on Aging reported that consumers lose around $40 billion annually to telemarketing fraud, with an estimated 10% of telemarketing firms being fraudulent. Only a small fraction of fraud victims report the crime. The Federal Bureau of Investigation warns that fraud targeting seniors is increasing, with criminals using online scams like phishing and email spamming in addition to traditional methods. Only a small percentage of fraud victims report the crime to authorities. The IC3, a partnership between the National White Collar Crime Center and the FBI, processed over 219,553 Internet crime complaints in 2007. They referred 90,008 complaints, totaling $239,090,000 in losses, to law enforcement agencies. Consumer awareness is crucial in preventing fraud. Centralized service established for educating seniors on mail, telemarketing, and internet fraud. The Federal Trade Commission will disseminate information on fraud targeting seniors and methods to report it. The Federal Trade Commission provides methods to report fraud targeting seniors, including referring complaints to law enforcement agencies and calling a national toll-free telephone number for reporting fraud. Additionally, they will provide publicly available information on any record of law enforcement in response to specific requests. The Federal Trade Commission will maintain a website as a resource for information on fraud targeting seniors and establish procedures for disseminating information on law enforcement actions against fraud. Authorization of Appropriations.-- $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2015 to implement requirements within one year of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. GRANTS TO PREVENT MAIL, TELEMARKETING, AND INTERNET FRAUD. The Attorney General will establish a grant program to fund fraud prevention education programs for seniors, in collaboration with various agencies. Eligible organizations include State Attorneys General, law enforcement agencies, senior centers, and nonprofit organizations. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this program. Authorization of Appropriations: $20,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2015. The Congress acknowledges the impact of fraud on senior citizens and proposes designating a week in May as "National Senior Fraud Awareness Week" to increase public awareness and prevent fraud against seniors. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
